channel.title: yudel tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from yudel.

item.description: @davewiner They value their relationships with Republicans (who are their owner’s social circle and their advertisers) more than they value our trust.
“It’s important to have a strong Republican Party.” [link]
@schwarz To be fair, he knows nothing about neuroscience and arguably far too little about Mars colonization.
@schwarz Oh, and self-driving cars.

@schwarz His neuroscience claims seem to be at least 20 years premature. Not a neuroscientist myself, but a family member is a postdoc and her research which is being published in a top journal is a long way from what EM’s researcher is promising.
@schwarz I suspect three researchers picked at random from Researchgate would say the same.

The Constitutional regime the Republican Barrett SCOTUS is teeing up will grant the Executive unlimited powers as Commander in Chief but no ability to be delegated Congressional authority for the General Welfare. [link]
@DavidRSelis Sadly, I don’t think my sister is high enough on the Getty hierarchy to simply move the collection across the street.
@trekonomics Tell me you don’t understand Ray Bradbury’s point without….
Literally pivoting to video. [link]
@YehudaKurtzer @ImTheQ Or the occasional special double sided tape. [link]
@trekonomics So he’s getting crazier. Expect FTL investments before he’s done.
@trekonomics I am willing to wager money that he will land a crew on Mars before he succeeds in offloading memories to silicon.
@trekonomics Both played a role in Altered Carbon, a very fun but fairly amoral noir cyberpunk novel that probably influenced him far more than did the KSR Mars trilogy.
@doctorow It may say “Disposable manuscript” but I’m still going to photocopy it if I want to read it on my 1985 subway ride home.

@dsquareddigest For what it’s worth, my two cents on military/foreign policy, as someone who is very much not focused on the field: 1) Before the Iraq War, I assumed the Bushies advocating it knew what they were doing, because military/foreign policy was their bailiwick. Fool me once…

@dsquareddigest 2) After we effectively lost the war waged in Afghanistan on a bipartisan basis, there has been absolutely no effort by Congress to figure out what we did wrong. Apparently, while funding the military is a bipartisan priority, neither party can be bothered to ensure it works.

@dsquareddigest Having read a grand total of one book on the military I’m certainly no expert, but that book compelling argued that the US Army, like many an enterprise, works to maximize the goals of each decision maker, rather than the professed corporate mission.

@dsquareddigest “The Perfect War” argues that body counts served the goals of war planners who wanted a metric, and killing civilians to inflate the body count served the goals of officers who were judged by that metric. It did not, however, actually help win the war. [link]
@dsquareddigest Having read again a total of one serious article about the Afghan war, it seems that similar policies which made bureaucratic sense but not strategic sense were at play there.

@dsquareddigest The fact that Congress is incapable of addressing this, whether because of capture by defense contractors or general stupidity or whatever, is deeply disturbing to me both as a taxpayer and as someone who doesn’t want to live under foreign occupation as described by @Ww3Real.

@Inkling61 @jayrosen_nyu They knew that their business model of providing news reporting wouldn't make Republicans gag wasn't compatible with the journalistic standards a Public Editor would hold them to, certainly not once the Republican party embraced Trump.
@Inkling61 @jayrosen_nyu With their advertisers and the owners' social set, if not the owners themselves, skewing Republican, the Times didn't really have a choice.
The question in evaluating Neuralink’s claims from the outside is this: [link]

Is it more likely that one scientist has advanced the state of the art in neuroscience by a couple of orders of magnitude? Or that one of the richest men in the world could be taken in by a con man who drops scientific jargon?
